Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 12:00PM MiracleMileM wrote: Dear Pee, I'm so sorry.   My heart and hugs go out to you   In looking at your and other people's situations, the end seems to sneak up and land on you with a ton of bricks.  I look at Elizabeth Edwards who bought a new house in October all full of plans and then. . . .   And the same with stage IV friends who are going along OK and then bam.  I'm impressed by your thoughtfulness and concern for those you will be leaving behind.  You set a high bar.  I've been trying to get rid of junk so that others will not have to deal with it but it is hard working 80% of full time when natural inclinations of procrastination combine with reduced energy.   If you are going with another round or two of chemo, think of doing so while taking paw-paw pills.  Can't hurt, low cost and the pills appear to be effective at knocking out chemo resistant cancer cells.  Look at these links.  That is what I would try.   http://www.pawpawresearch.com/pawpaw-trials1.pdf http://www.pawpawresearch.com/purdue-mdr-97.htm http://www.pawpawresearch.com/ http://alternativecancer.us/acetogenins1999.pdf http://www.annieappleseedproject.org/pawpawfruita.html http://www.pdazzler.com/archives/239 http://alternativecancer.us/pawpaw.htm http://www.smashcancer.com/2010/08/10/paw-paw-alternative-cancer-treatment-part-9/ http://www.treelite.com/downloads/PawPawCell-Reg.pdf
Posts.Title: Seems as if time is running out... pee vision2020

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2014 03:05PM - edited Aug 17, 2014 03:27PM by MiracleMileM What I find particularly upsetting is the failure in many cases to routinely do initial PET scans as a standard part of the staging protocol.  I have friends who have been diagnosed and treated as stage II or III, who think they have kicked it when in fact it was probably stage IV out of the box - something which probably would have been identified with a PET and other scans.   They have been given the illusory sense that they have kicked it.  They have been denied the benefit of staging treatment based on all the information.  When I see women on these boards with a stage IV diagnosis a short time period after an initial diagnosis, I suspect this failure.  I think this kicking cancer mentality is combined sometimes with a diagnostic bias of not looking too deeply in favor of a "happy ending" wrapped in a pink ribbon.  I am glad I always chose the more expensive option of PPO coverage although I only exceeded my deductible in one year before being diagnosed with mbc in 2007.  And glad my primary care physician linked me to an excellent hospital outpatient progam with a tumor board and with a culture of fighting to get the recommended diagnostic and treatment options.
Posts.Title: Oncologist Takes on Amy Robach's Pink Warrior Rhetoric EnglishMajor Marple

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2016 03:17PM - edited Mar 26, 2016 03:32PM by MiracleMileM I've been receiving herceptin infusions since December 22, 2007. EFs all stable. NED since about September of 2008. About 18 months ago i went to every 4 weeks infusions instead of every 3 weeks. In part that was because i was getting Xgeva shots every 4 weeks and I did not like going in twice a month. My oncologist was chary about the change in light of no studies or protocols on 4 weeks versus 3 weeks. But I have remained stable so no current objection. He prescribes the same dosage as before. I sense that the herceptin remains at therapeutic levels because my herceptin drippy nose etc. continues unabated in the week before infusion. So Muggleborn, talk to your oncologist about returning to herceptin every 4 weeks or once a month at least to start. I'm with Cafelovr. Insist on sticking with what works; HERCEPTIN. I would never risk going off herceptin. I credit Herceptin with my being here at all. In my opinion too risky to stay off herceptin. Best regards.
Posts.Title: Stopping Herceptin MuggleBorn Cafelovr

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 07:00PM MiracleMileM wrote:  If there are social workers where you get your treatment, see if they can help with getting your oncologist to document the over all impact of your cancer on your ability to function on the job:  significantly reduced stamina, need for a nap every day, joint side effects expecially if any of the joint problems impact your hands, absence a day every three weeks for herceptin infusion, brain fog and/or bowel problems if those are SE that apply you, etc.    SSA is more interested in  the diagnoses and limitations than your doctor's conclusion about whether or not you can work.  And frankly, I question wether doctors are actually equipped to determine that.  A friend after complicated eye surgery was told yes, you can go to work.  You just can' read, laugh, or lift anything over a pound or two. I agree with other posters about getting representation if improved medical documentation does not fix things at reconsideration.  Another problem may have been happy talk when you filled out the daily activity report.  We are so used to downplaying the way the cancer and treatment interferes with our functioning that that may have done you in. When you request the reconsideration, go to the SSA office in person and ask for a copy of the medical file.  That will include both the medical evidence the disability determination service had when it made the decision as well as internal processing and thinking of the evaluators.  Be adamant about getting a copy!  You may find that important informtion did not make it into your file - gaps that you can fix.  I also recommend that you get the telephone number of the disability determination unit making the reconsideration determination so that you can make personal contact.  On the reconsideration form where it asks about additional evidence, write this:  yes - when I and my treatment team have reviewed the file to see what is missing. Finally, in many circuits, if your treating physician says you meet the listing of impairments and documents why, then the burden shifts to SSA to show why you are not medically eligible.  Go here to get to SSA's program rules including regulations:   http://www.ssa.gov/regulations/ Then go to regulations and click on "404."  The listing of ipairments including for cancer - #13 malignant neoplastic - are in the appendix following 404.1599.  You look like you meet the criteria for 13.10 but read the preface to the individual listings. Good luck.  If you get the documentation to the disability determination service - usually a unit within the state government that contracts with SSA and operates under SSA's  jurisdiction, I think you will have a good shot at turning this around at reconsideration.   About paying your premiums, ask the social workers where you get your herceptin infusions for some short-term help in defraying the cost of the premiums while you get over this hump.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2015 04:36PM MiracleMileM wrote: if your blog name means you live in New York, check our State insurance and health plan laws. In California the health plans have to provide you with a copy of any guidelines used to make decisions. Perjeta has been around enough for there to be a guideline. Likely New York has consumer protections similar to what is available in California. Under federal Medicaid managed care rules the person denying something must have clinical experience and expertise. If you are part of an IPA, it is often the medical director of the IPA making the decision, rather than someone with relevant clinical expertise. In California if you appeal the initial adverse decision, the state health plan laws require that the person making the appeal decision have clinical experience and expertise. Finally, check with your doctor's office about what Medicare does. It is usually difficult for a health plan to deny you something Medicare routinely covers. Good luck and appeal if your doctor does not come back with a "yes."
Posts.Title: Anyone have problems getting insurance to approve Perjeta? Brooklyn MiracleMileM

Posts.Content: May 18, 2011 03:32PM MiracleMileM wrote: Like Chainsawz, I would never be able to keep straight who I told what. I have been pretty open about everything with everyone.   I have a very supportive work situation (I'm working 80% now) and supportive family and friends.  I keep my secretary abreast of everything and if anyone wants to know something, they contact her.  When I was first diagnosed and went through treatment, I characterized my BC as "locally advanced" which means III-B or III-C.  That characterization was fairly accurate because my mets are confined to the left side of my chest and, except for a met spot on cartilege near the left collarbone, are all clumped around the tumor site - ribs, sternum, nodes under sternum - maybe oligometastatic.  Toward the end of 2008 (diagnosed 12-1-07) and following all the treatment I was classified as NED so that I felt I had a better chance at making it to year five.  I then told people I was Stage IV,   I strongly believe that low vitamin D levels contributed to my getting BC so one of my missions is to tell my sunscreen slathering friends to up their vitamin D intake and to get their levels tested.   When I have to deal with progression, I think I'll use caringbridge.  I have been impressed by its usefullness in sharing information.
Posts.Title: how many people have you told apple blondiex46

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 02:34PM MiracleMileM wrote: Try taking some magnesium - or a hot bath with epsom salts because the magnesium will be absorbed through the skin.  Each of my two calcium tablets contains 250 mg of magnesium (63% of DV each) and there is 110 mg (27% of DV) in my multivitamin.  I take in addition 100 mg (25% DV) and found that the occasional pains down left leg stopped.  For me the link between not enough for me magnesium and leg cramps became clear when I forgot to take the evening calcium with magnesium and then would get the leg cramps at night.
Posts.Title: Muscle pain? TXGigi apple

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2015 04:55PM MiracleMileM wrote: I was switched from zometa to xgeva about two years ago. I have not had problems with either. I have been NED for over seven years. I switched my herceptin from every 3 weeks to every 4 weeks. That way I go into the hospital outpatient clinic only once a month. Re the xgeva I make sure the shot is not cold. I take it in my arm/wings and ask that it be injected very, very slowly. I rag doll myself so it does not hurt - just uncomfortable. Re side effects, I don't know if I can distinguish between herceptin and xgeva. I schedule my infusions for late in the day so that I can minimize the impact on work. Afterwards I go home and sleep. I agree with the person who recommends drinking a lot of water.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2015 07:40PM MiracleMileM wrote: Dear Marvass, I am so sorry that your wife has to go back to IT herceptin. Keep us posted. Since apparently up to 50% of those with stage IV HER2+++ end up with brain mets, your wife's journey has been inspirational to me. Thank you for sharing it. I was diagnosed stage IV the beginning of December 2007 and, thanks to Herceptin, have been NED now for 7 years. And comforting me also was Sbidalia's report that her daughter was receiving IT herceptin at Cedars-Sinai in Los Angeles, where I go for treatment albeit for leptomeningeal metastases rather than brain mets per se.. But close enough to give me hope that I could get IT herceptin if I develop brain mets because herceptin works so well for me against my breast cancer. Marvass, you may want to consider your wife taking what I take in the hopes of reducing my risk of brain mets: On an empty stomach, 1500 mg green tea extract with quercetin. The empty stomach and quercetin enhance absorption. And with meals 3500-4000 mgs a day divided of curcumin - Drs best C-3 and curcumin phytosome. both pass the blood brain barrier and there is evidence for both of anti-tumor properties.

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2010 04:21PM - edited Jun 12, 2010 04:23PM by MiracleMileM I hated Decadron which I took before and with each of my chemos and for my initial Herceptin and Zometa infusions.  I would have insisted on boswellia serrata if I had know it was an option.  I use boswellia serrata now for joint side effects from arimidex etc. along with other stuff.   There is lots of stuff out there on boswellia including for cerebral edema and as a treatment for brain mets and primary brain tumors.   To get to pdf'd 2007 article by Narda Robinson, google "benefits of boswellia" & Narda Robinson.  Footnote 25 cites to research on use of boswellia to address cerebral edema.  Here are some other reports:  http://www.cancersalves.com/botanical_approaches/individual_herbs/boswellia.html http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16223251 http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00243022 http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials/CASE-CCF-7348 Look at footnote 11 in this article:  http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6882/9/6 http://naturalformulations.net/coofcaab.html Go for the boswellia. [Stage IV diagnosed 12-1-07 ER+PR+ HER+++ , shunt inserted & chemo (TCH) begun 2d week of Decemger, lumpectomy May, IMRT radiation 36 sessions June-July, Zometa & Herceptin infusions continuing indefinitely since June 08, NED for past 18 months.]

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 03:07AM MiracleMileM wrote: Dear Jac53, The suggestion about considering boswellia as an alternative to decadron was directed to how decadron is used - namely as an anti-inflammatory that passes through the blood-brain barrier to reduce brain swelling or edema from the radiation or brain met tumors themselves rather than the underlying brain mets.  But boswellia shows some promise of also slowing or stopping breast cancer.  Maybe using boswellia for brain swelling might have a positive side effect.  Here are some articles that suggest that:  http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6882/11/129/abstract http://www.collmed.org/fulltext.pdf  http://naturalformulations.net/coofcaab.html http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3153165/?tool=pmcentrez

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2010 09:47PM MiracleMileM wrote: You can get an 11-month extension if you can meet the Social Security definition of disability.  Social Security will make a disability determination independent of an application for benefits. You can qualify for an extension of COBRA benefits by getting a disability determination from SSA even if you would not qualify for SSI because of income or resources or Social Security Disability Insurance Benefits because not enough of a work history.  Or if you simply elect not to apply for benefits. Federal law provides that a person who qualifies for 18 months of COBRA benefits - i.e., private health care benefits you pay for following termination of employment - may have those benefits extended an additional 11 months to 29 months total if there is a disability determination by the Social Security Administration that the person met the Social Security disability standard in the first 60 days of the initial COBRA coverage and currently meets that standard.  29 U.S.C. §§ 1161 et seq., 26 U.S.C. § 4980B.  The Social Security Administration, through its Federal Disability Determination Service, makes the COBRA-only determination of disability for adults and children who do not meet the SSI income and/or resource eligibility standards or who do not qualify for SSDI benefits on grounds other than disability such as not enough of a work history or who simply elect not to apply for benefits.   There used to be a section in the public POMS (Program Operations Manual System, SSA's internal guidelines) on the Social Security website that explained the COBRA-only disability determination process.  Unfortunately that POMS section is no longer a part of the public POMS but may be a part of the POMS available electronically to the local Social Security office.  The local office collects the medical reports and information you have and gets you to sign medical releases just as it would for any disability determination case.  In addition, the local office gets information about the deadline for getting the determination (i.e., before the 18-month regular COBRA period expires) and when the initial 60-day period starts and ends because there needs to be a determination that COBRA insured person met the Social Security disability standard within that time period in addition to currently meeting the standard.  The local Social Security Office forwards the package to:           Federal Disability Determination Service                    Office of Disability, Social Security Administration                    6-G-21 Dickinson Tower                    P.O. Box 17357                    Baltimore MD 21241 I recommend that you provide the local office with a copy of this reply to explain what you are asking for.  If there is nothing in the POMS available to the field office or there is any question about the procedure to be followed including what "special handling" flags should be used, the local office will check with its regional office or with the federal DDS directly.  Ask for a contact name and telephone number or fax number so that you can send in additional information and reports directly to the federal DDS. If you run into any problems getting your request for a COBRA-only disability determination, contact your local congressional office.  Ask to speak with the person who handles constituent problems with Social Security.  This reply may also explain the help you need and the urgency.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 03:23PM MiracleMileM wrote: Like JeninMichigan I have been NED since the middle of 2008 and have continued on herceptin every 3 weeks and now on xgeva shot every 4 weeks.  My oncologist says standard protocol is to continue on herceptin until there is progression or a need for holiday because of echo results.   My infusion center reports that there is a patient there who has been on herceptin for about nine years which makes me very optimistic about my future.  I strongly recommend staying with what works and getting a second opinion because your oncologist appears to be outside of the mainstream.  Herceptin has been like a miracle for me

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2013 04:46PM MiracleMileM wrote: NickyJ, Let us know what happens.  Yes, the metsters here are totally rooting for you. Another reason for not stopping the herceptin is our stage IV special risk for brain mets since herceptin does not pass through the blood brain barrier.  (I'm taking a bunch of supplements I hope will protect the brain.)  I think the herceptin keeps whatever cancer cells are floating through our systems down to a minimum  thereby reducing our risk for brain mets. You are in my thoughts.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 08:28PM MiracleMileM wrote: Dear Chk8: Your initial period of COBRA is 18 months with an 11-month extension if Social Security has determined that you meet the SS definition of disability.  COBRA benefits stop whenever you qualify for Medicare whether through Social Security disability benefits or turning 65.  Even if you do not qualify for benefits for nondisability reasons, Social Security has a procedure for making a disability determination for purposes of qualifying for the 11-month COBRA extension.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 10:33PM MiracleMileM wrote: I was diagnoised as triple positive Stage IV initially in December of 2007.  A big honking left side tumor on my ribs under my breast toward the midline:  mets to ribs, sternum, nodes under breastbone, and cartilege up by shoulder.   I had 6 sessions of TCH which shrank the tumor a whole lot followed by a lumpectomy - also placed markers for the IMRT radiation that followed.  Like OnMyOwn I was glad to get rid of that stinking mothership tumor even if a shadow of its former self.  I continue with Arimidex, Herceptin and Xgeva.  My breast doesn't look too wierd.  NED well over two years.   Stage IV lumpectomies are fairly standard after chemo where I go for treatment.
